Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis and Design Workshop: The Future of Embodied Design for Mathematical Imagination and Cognition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The next generation of digital learning environments for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) content will be more interactive, more personalized yet more collaborative; provide developers and teachers with rich, real time data from users to track engagement and support formative assessment; and target both conscious and unconscious learning processes. Embodied cognition research provides promising findings that show how body movement contributes to STEM education by allowing learners to physically engage with ideas, and by describing how teachers naturally use their bodies in ways such as gestures to enhance their instructional effectiveness. Mathematics education, in particular, can benefit from such innovation in embodied cognition because it serves as the connective representational "language" across the STEM fields. Technologies exist now that can track people's movement in real time and provide feedback. Yet there is no current consensus on the best ways to design educational technology for supporting embodied cognition for mathematics education. The timing for motion capture technology, theories of embodied cognition, and interest among teachers for movement based educational innovations is ideal for bringing scholars and classroom practitioners together for a workshop on embodied design for mathematics education. During a 3-day workshop at the University of Wisconsin-Madison in the spring of 2019, teachers and research scholars will gather to discuss ways in which new computer technologies support embodied approaches for improved math education. The workshop participants examine learning in and out of school, but with a focus on the design of systems for promoting embodied ways of learning and teaching in classroom settings.

Embodied design for mathematics education, a research-oriented pedagogical design framework rooted in theories of embodiment and design-based research as practiced within the learning sciences, supports the improvement of instructional methodology for students' mathematical proficiency in the classroom. Currently there is a convergence of theoretical, technological, and methodological developments in formation that make this a particularly promising time to support advancements in embodied design for mathematics education. The workshop will bring research scholars and classroom teachers together in order to achieve four central objectives: (1) synthesize current research into a coherent theory of embodied mathematical imagination and cognition, (2) identify the most promising opportunities for conceptual and methodological integration, (3) curate a set of evidence-based design principles for enhancing mathematics education and broadening participation in all STEM fields, and (4) articulate a future research agenda in the growing area of embodied cognition. This workshop will assemble an interdisciplinary set of scholars from education research, cognitive science, the learning sciences, developmental psychology, movement science, linguistics, computer science, and mathematics. Presentations and discussions will span grades K through 16 on topics in arithmetic and algebra, proportional reasoning and fractions, geometry, complex numbers, statistics, and calculus. The workshop will bring together an intellectually and ethnically diverse group of scholars to synthesize the evidence for embodied design as a means to enhance mathematical reasoning and thereby promote STEM education and participation. The workshop organization will promote interdisciplinary research and theory building in the learning sciences and identify current challenges and future research efforts. The approach is tightly connected to the societal need to foster an educated and technically competent workforce. A particular emphasis on mathematics is intended to broaden participation in math and STEM by creating new entry points for historically underserved ethnic, racial, economic, and gender groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are witnessing a powerful convergence of three advancements for effective, novel innovations in STEM education: emerging theories of embodied learning and teaching; accessible and programmable motion-capture sensors to expand human?computer interaction platforms (e.g., using gesture and gaze); and methods for measuring, modeling, and monitoring individual and collective student activity in real time (multimodal data analytics, artificial intelligence, machine learning, and visualization). This convergence is fueling growth in understanding Embodied Mathematical Imagination & Cognition (EMIC).

 

Intellectual merit of this work is to (1) host an international workshop on The Future of Embodied Design for Mathematical Imagination and Cognition that included scholars, designers and math educators; (2) produce a white paper; and (3) disseminate findings through (3a) website and (3b) major publication. Additionally, objectives for the workshop were to: (1a) begin synthesizing a coherent theory of EMIC, (1b) identify areas for methodological and technological integration, (1c) curate and disseminate evidence-based design principles for broadening participation in STEM fields, and (1d) articulate a future research agenda.

 

Broader impacts of this  project are to articulate evidence-based design principles for broadening participation in STEM, especially for reaching students from historically underrepresented groups. and offer a future research agenda for understanding and promoting EMIC. These aims are tightly connected to the societal need to foster an educated and technically competent workforce. Our particular emphasis is to broaden participation in mathematics and STEM by creating new entry points through nonverbal, embodied means that may serve linguistically diverse and historically underserved ethnic, racial, economic, and gender groups.  

 

We successfully hosted a 3-day workshop during May 20-22, 2019 at the University of Wisconsin, in Madison, WI (USA) with scholars, designers and K-16 math educators. We produced a white paper for NSF. We created a website that documents the event and participants (embodiedmathematics.com). We published a major article ?The future of embodied design for mathematics teaching and learning? in Frontiers in Education (open access). The white paper and Frontiers article offer a preliminary synthesis of current theories of EMIC, identify current and future areas of technological and methodological integration, summarize evidence-based design principles for broadening participation in STEM, especially for reaching students from historically underrepresented groups, and offer a research agenda for understanding and promoting EMIC. Thus we achieved items (1), (2), (3a) and (3b).

 

 

These design principles emerged:

 

(A) Embodied activities provide historically underrepresented learners and learners who consider themselves ?unteachable? new points of access to mathematical ideas through movement, concrete experiences, and collaborative, physical engagement. All students need to develop a multimodal voice for expressing what they know through verbal and nonverbal forms, and for effective collaboration.

 

(B) Teacher education for EMIC belongs in content methods courses and K?16 professional development, where they experience and then facilitate mathematical engagement via physical or virtual movement among individuals and collaborative interaction.

 

(C) Gestures use in instruction and formative assessment is necessary to meet the ideals of EMIC. Learners regularly convey their knowledge through gestures (in addition to speech). Learners? gestures can provide a ?leading edge? of where students? thinking is headed, and which students are most ready to made conceptual leaps. Teachers can learn to read and utilize this information from student gestures. Instructional gestures are also effective for directing student attention, making explicit connections and comparisons, and for fostering common ground (e.g., through iconic and metaphorical gestures). Teachers can also learn to adopt effective instructional gesture practices.

 

We also identified these areas of most promising future research and development that are relevant to all STEM education and career pathways:

 

(A)  How meaning of mathematical concepts is grounded in movement, perception, and other nonverbal and non-symbolic processes; and how these complement and integrate with knowledge that is linguistic, symbolic and verbalizable. These are identified as especially valuable for students with limited English proficiency, as well as all learners who struggle to adopt new, technical vocabulary for mathematical reasoning, problem solving and proof. This has the potential to address longstanding theoretical questions of how meaning is made and how novel ideas and abstract symbols gain meaning.

 

(B) How learners in EMIC activities discover and develop intuitions and insights about mathematical phenomena, even when they are not aware of their own learning; whether it is best to sometimes or always make these tacit forms of knowledge explicit for learners; and how to most effectively do that. This has the potential to address longstanding theoretical questions of the relationship between implicit and explicit knowledge.

 

(C) How to best leverage collaborative engagement in service of both linguistic and embodied interactions around mathematical phenomena. While the most common platforms for delivering embodied interventions (laptops and tablets) are limited for supporting equitable collaboration, advancements in head-mounted systems offer promising new technological platforms. This has the potential to address longstanding theoretical questions of the role of common ground and bridging individual and collective knowledge.
